chapter.title: Configuring Your System
chapter.para: This chapter contains information on configuring your system.

sect1.title: Desktop Tricks
sect1.para: This section details some tips for using and customising Ubuntu's desktop environment (called GNOME), and the file manager (called Nautilus).

sect2.title: Run programs automatically when GNOME starts

step.para: Choose &sessions;
Click on the Startup Programs tab.
Use the Add, Edit, and Delete buttons to manage programs to run at startup. Some programs will automatically add themselves to this list when you configure them.

sect2.title: Menu Editing
sect2.para: Ubuntu comes with the Alacarte Menu Editor, so you can customize your menus and add entries for applications that don't automatically appear after they are installed.
To add a new menu entry:

step.para: Open Alacarte with &menu-editor;, or by right-clicking on any menu and choosing Edit Menus.
In Alacarte's left-hand pane, choose the submenu the new entry should appear in.

Choose
File New Entry . In the New Entry window, choose a Name, Comment, Command and Icon. The Command will usually be the package name, Name is what will appear on the menu, and the Comment will appear in the tooltip that appears near the menu entry. Icons are added to the /usr/share/pixmaps directory by default, or can be chosen from anywhere in your files.

sect2.para: To change the order of menu entries, use the up and down arrows on the right-hand side of the Alacarte window.
To stop a menu entry from being displayed, use the checkboxes beside each entry. This does not erase the menu entry, so you can restore it later in the same way.

sect2.title: Change Display Mode in Nautilus
sect2.para: Nautilus provides two modes in which you can interact with your filesystem: Spatial mode and Browser mode.

listitem.para: In Browser mode, the file manager window represents a browser, which can display any location. Opening a folder updates the current file manager window to show the contents of the new folder.

In Spatial mode, the file manager window represents a particular folder. Opening a folder opens the new window for that folder. Each time you open a particular folder, you will find its window displayed in the same place on the screen and the same size as the last time you viewed it (this the reason for the name).

sect2.para: Browser mode is the default setting on Ubuntu, but you may wish to change this:

step.para:
In Nautilus, choose
Edit Preferences .
Click on the Behavior tab.
Unselect the Always open in browser windows check box.
Close and reopen Nautilus.

sect2.title: Show hidden files and folders in Nautilus

step.para:
In Nautilus, use the Ctrl H shortcut keys to toggle hidden files and folders on and off, or
View Show Hidden Files .

To permanently show all hidden files and folders, choose
Edit Preferences .
Click on the Views tab.
Select the Show hidden and backup files check box.

sect2.title: Open the Location Bar in Nautilus
sect2.para:
The Location Bar is the bar in your file manager in which you can type an address. Toggle the bar on and off with:
Go Location...
You can also use the Ctrl L shortcut keys.

sect2.title: View remote SSH, FTP, and SFTP servers using Nautilus

step.para: Make sure the Nautilus Location Bar is open (see ).
In the Location Bar, enter the following:
For SSH, use: ssh://username@ssh.server.com
For FTP, use: ftp://username@ftp.server.com
For SFTP, use: sftp://username@sftp.server.com

Replace username with your username and replace everything after the @ symbol with the server's address. You will be prompted for a password if needed. If there is no username (anonymous) omit the username and the @ symbol.
Alternatively, to specify your password manually, change one of the above like so: ftp://username:password@ftp.server.com

sect2.title: Change the default file type "Open with" program

step.para:
In Nautilus, right click on the file and choose
Properties
from the menu that appears. The Properties dialog opens.
Click on the Open With tab. A list of applications appears.
Select the default application you want for the file type. If the application is not on the list, use the Add button to add the application to the list.

sect2.title: Digital Cameras
sect2.para: Most USB digital cameras will be automatically detected by Ubuntu. Simply plug in and switch on your USB digital camera, Ubuntu will then ask you if you would like to import the photos from your camera. Click on Import, Ubuntu will then show you a preview of your photos. Choose a location to save your photos to, then click on Import, Ubuntu will then save your photos to your hard drive.

sect2.title: Wireless Cards
sect2.para: Many wireless cards are automatically detected by Ubuntu during installation. A complete listing of wireless cards which work with Ubuntu can be found on Ubuntu Wiki. Please add your wireless card to the list if it works with Ubuntu.

Some cards may not work "out of the box" with Ubuntu. If this is the case, please look at the Wireless Troubleshooting Guide on the Ubuntu Wiki which is an excellent resource for troubleshooting wireless cards.
All information regarding wireless networking on Ubuntu is collected at Wireless Networking Central on the Ubuntu Wiki.

sect3.title: Winmodems
sect3.para: Most winmodems are not supported by Ubuntu, but drivers can be found that will enable the use of such modems. First you need to identify what chipset your winmodem is using:

para.screen: wget -c &scanmodem-url; gunzip -c &scanmodem-gz; > scanModem chmod +x scanModem sudo ./scanModem gedit Modem/ModemData.txt

sect3.para: Check the output in Gedit, it should list what modem chipset you have. Once you are aware of the chipset you have, see &linmodem; and follow the directions for your modem. More infomation can be found at SettingUpModems on the Ubuntu Wiki.

sect3.title: ADSL Modems
sect3.para: All PPPOE and router-style ADSL modems are supported by Ubuntu (that use ethernet for the connections), and some USB ADSL modems are supported too. For router-style ADSL modems, just connect it up, configure the modem as per your ISPs instructions and configure networking in Ubuntu. For information on PPPOE modems see ADSLPPoE on the Ubuntu wiki.

sect3.title: Firestarter Firewall
sect3.para: A firewall protects a computer system from unauthorized access. It is not normally necessary to install a firewall on an Ubuntu system, because by default access to the system is closed. However, if you run any services which you allow other computers to access (for example, the Apache web server), it is advisable to install a firewall. Firestarter is a program which allows you to control a firewall through a graphical interface.

step.para: Install the Firestarter package from the Universe repository (see ).
After it is installed, run &firestarter-firewall-tool; to configure your firewall. The firewall will now start in the background when your computer starts.
